Literature Review:
The field of psycholinguistics has seen a significant increase in the complexity and sophistication of data analysis techniques over the past few decades. This literature review aims to highlight some of the best practices in analyzing (psycho)linguistic data, focusing on frequentist and Bayesian linear mixed models. The review will also discuss the importance of hypothesis testing using Bayes factors, estimation, and uncertainty quantification, while emphasizing the need to avoid overstating the evidence and setting realistic expectations for statistical outcomes.

One of the primary challenges in (psycho)linguistic data analysis is the inherent variability in human language processing. Traditional statistical methods, such as t-tests and ANOVA, often fail to account for this variability, leading to potential misinterpretations of results. Linear mixed models (LMMs) have emerged as a robust alternative, allowing researchers to model both fixed and random effects simultaneously (Baayen, Davidson, & Bates, 2008). LMMs can handle hierarchical data structures, such as multiple observations per participant or item, and provide more accurate estimates of variance components (Barr, Levy, Scheepers, & Tily, 2013).

Frequentist approaches to LMMs typically involve hypothesis testing using p-values and confidence intervals. However, the reliance on p-values has been criticized for several reasons. First, p-values do not provide direct evidence for the null hypothesis; they only indicate the probability of observing the data given that the null hypothesis is true (Wasserstein & Lazar, 2016). Second, p-values are sensitive to sample size, leading to the paradoxical situation where large samples can produce statistically significant results even when the effect size is trivial (Cohen, 1994). To address these issues, researchers have increasingly turned to Bayesian methods, which offer a more nuanced approach to statistical inference.

Bayesian linear mixed models (BLMMs) incorporate prior knowledge into the analysis, allowing for more flexible and interpretable results. Bayes factors, a key component of Bayesian hypothesis testing, provide a measure of the relative evidence for the null hypothesis versus the alternative hypothesis (Jeffreys, 1961). Unlike p-values, Bayes factors can support the null hypothesis and provide a continuous measure of evidence, making them particularly useful in (psycho)linguistic research where effect sizes are often small (Dienes, 2014). Moreover, Bayesian methods naturally handle uncertainty quantification through posterior distributions, which can be used to estimate credible intervals and make probabilistic statements about parameters (Kruschke, 2015).

Simulation is another powerful tool in the (psycho)linguistic data analyst's toolkit. Before conducting an experiment, researchers can simulate data based on different experimental designs to understand the properties of their planned analysis (Gelman & Carlin, 2014). This approach helps in identifying potential issues, such as low power or biased estimates, and allows researchers to optimize their design for better statistical performance. Simulation can also be used post-hoc to validate the results of a fitted model, ensuring that the model behaves as expected under various conditions (Gelman & Shalizi, 2013).

Visualization plays a crucial role in the exploratory phase of data analysis. Plotting raw data and summary statistics can reveal patterns and outliers that might be missed in a formal analysis (Tukey, 1977). Visual inspection of data can also help in diagnosing model fit and identifying potential sources of bias. For instance, residual plots can indicate whether the assumptions of the model are met, and interaction plots can highlight complex relationships between variables (Cleveland, 1993).

In conclusion, the analysis of (psycho)linguistic data requires a thoughtful and methodical approach. Frequentist and Bayesian linear mixed models offer robust tools for handling complex data structures, while hypothesis testing using Bayes factors and uncertainty quantification provide a more nuanced understanding of the evidence. Simulation and visualization are essential components of the data analysis process, helping researchers to design better experiments and interpret their results more accurately. By adopting these best practices, researchers can enhance the reliability and validity of their findings, contributing to the advancement of the field.
